The Assembly of Experts will have the final say.  Dateline 10-13-15 The Iranian Parliament voted (Guardian) on Tuesday to support the nuclear agreement negotiated with world powers in July in a vote of 161-59, with thirteen abstentions. The agreement, in which Iran will roll back its nuclear program in exchange for an easing of sanctions, will be reviewed by senior clerics for final approval before it can be implemented.  Daily Brief: Council on Foreign Relations [dailybrief@e.cfr.org]

In the latest Iranian parliamentary session carried live by state radio, 161 lawmakers voted for implementing the nuclear deal, while 59 voted against it and 13 abstained. Another 17 did not vote at all, while 40 lawmakers did not attend the session. The Supreme Leader has stated that parliament will make the final decision.

http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=250028 Oct 12.  "Iranian lawmakers on Sunday approved the general outlines of a motion on a nuclear deal signed between Iran and the 5+1 group of world powers on a conditional basis.
. . . 
"According to the motion, the Iranian administration has to actively pursue the policy of global nuclear disarmament and participate in all international, legal and diplomatic efforts in this regard. It also stipulates that the administration should stop its voluntary activities and adopt reciprocal measures to restore the rights of the Iranian nation in case the other side violates the terms of the agreement, particularly on the issue of the Western-led sanctions.  "The details of the motion, proposed by Parliament National Security and Foreign Policy Committee, must now pass a second vote on Tuesday before being submitted to the Guardian Council for final approval.  "The ratification of the single-urgency motion would now give the go-ahead to the administration to voluntarily implement the agreement.
. . . 
"According to the motion, any visit by inspectors of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) should be conducted in line with international regulations and Iran’s national security. It also urges the Rouhani administration to fully protect Iran’s classified military and security information and prohibit any type of IAEA access to the country’s military sites under the pretext of implementing the JCPOA.

Darn, I keep on trying to decide how the scorers would rule.  Technically, the Majlis does not have to vote as this is purely advisory. So given how controversial this is, it might never come to a vote.  Technically, the measure that was reported out of committee places restrictions on the deal that some might see as serious enough that to pass the measure would actually be a rejection of the deal.  OTOH, since the vote is not binding, it would be easy for the scorers, the diplomatic community, mainstream media to count passage of this measure as being good enough to count as acceptance. Meanwhile, Iran deal sceptics will make a fuss and be ignored.  So, how is this for an analysis of a messy situation? Raising to 95% and holding my nose.
Decided to go with the flow. Expect a "yes" as long as the Iranian Parliament does not actively squelch the JCPA. Not much time left, but they need the agreement.

Iran wants as much money as it can lay its hands on. Price of oil tanked. Mullahs must feed masses.  Mullahs understand that access to Swift, ability to export crude are  100% essential to prevent regime change.  So the Parliament has to follow Khamenei and he really loses nothing to get these crtical assets.

Sounds like a done deal.  Looks like this weekend. http://en.trend.az/iran/politics/2440879.html  (Or maybe later this month? http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=249860) But cmeinel has raised some doubt about technical resolutions vs. question intent. I'm not planning on digging into the technicalities; it's "probably" safe to assume Iran doesn't reject the deal then the question will be resolved "yes" (similar to what JP says in an earlier comment).

This is more a case of second guessing the scorers. Presuming that the Majlis would vote on the "motion" released by the committee studying the nuclear deal, is this a motion agreeing to the deal, or disagreeing from it? It seems to prohibit the central goal of the deal, which is to prevent development on nuclear weapons. Does this feature of the motion support or oppose this goal: "It also urges the Rouhani administration to safeguard Iran’s classified military and security information and prohibit any type of IAEA access to the country’s military sites under the pretext of implementing the nuclear deal."  Now how can inspectors search for a secret nuclear weapons program if they are banned from "any type of IAEA access to the country's military sites..."? I'm guessing the resolution of this question will be heavily driven by the political biases of the scorers. There was considerable conflict in this game over the Parchin inspection on the grounds that Iranian officials did the inspection under the direction of IAEA rather than independently. So this suggests a bias among the scorers toward deciding that either the nuclear deal will be adhered to without any inspections of military facilities, or else that this clause doesn't mean anything. Therefore, raising probability to 50% under protest in that I am assuming that the scorers will make an biased decision inconsistent with my reading of the motion. But if anyone cares about my real -- fact based -- prediction, it's 0% now.
The Iranian government is on track to approve the JCPA by Nov 1, 2015

According to the motion, signed by 75 lawmakers, the Iranian administration has to actively pursue the policy of global nuclear disarmament and participate in all international, legal and diplomatic efforts in this regard.The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, also known as JCPOA, is based on cooperation and mutual respect between Iran and the P5+1 group of countries, the motion states, adding that any pressure and threat against Iran would lead to a review of bilateral cooperation.
The motion stipulates that the Iranian administration should stop its voluntary activities and adopt reciprocal measures to restore the rights of the Iranian nation in case the other side violates the terms of the agreement, particularly on the Western sanctions.
http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/10/four-ministers-warn-rouhani-economy.html?utm_source=Al-Monitor+Newsletter+%5BEnglish%5D&utm_campaign=94841768f4-October_06_2015&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_28264b27a0-94841768f4-102297633
The letter stated that there are eight reasons for the “rare decline” in Iran’s economy, such as sanctions and the drop in oil prices, but added that “uncoordinated decisions and policies” of various governmental agencies is the primary reason for the current economic situation.
After the letter was published in the Iranian media, Teyebnia told Iranian television that upon receiving the letter, Rouhani had ordered officials “to review again the capital market situation and [state] of the economy and for new polices to be created when necessary.”
Shargh daily asked why the four ministers would write to the president to address issues for which they themselves are responsible. According to experts who spoke with Shargh, the letter was meant to serve as a warning to Iranian parliamentarians to vote in favor of implementing the final nuclear agreement. Iranian officials opposed to the nuclear agreement, which would remove economic sanctions in return for reduced nuclear activity, have argued that Iran can pull itself out of its current economic situation by relying on domestic production rather than international markets.
"Adoption Day" is estimated for Oct 18. That involves actually starting the process of moving out centrifuges, etc. I don't think that will start without approval of the Parliament.

October 04, 2015 - 14:53.  "The Iranian parliament on Sunday approved a motion necessitating immediate work on a plan which would oblige the administration to take “proportional measures” in implementation of a comprehensive nuclear deal with six world powers. The motion was initially tagged with a "double urgency" status, but the lawmakers ratified it as a motion with single urgency. "Parliament Speaker Ali Larijani then tasked the National Security and Foreign Policy Commission with reviewing the proposed motion and making a report to the legislators. "With a single urgency of the motion ratified, it will be put to the vote again within the next 20 days. "The plan, if approved, will oblige the administration to start honoring commitments under a nuclear deal with the Group 5+1  . . .
~~~~~~~

Currently it looks increasingly likely that the Majlis  (Parliament) will not vote on anything that could be interpreted as a nuclear deal. Not ever. The reason: the nuclear deal can go through without them; instead, the Assembly of Experts has the right to take on this thankless, controversial job, according to the options offered by the Ayatollah. In any event, the committee that has been holding hearings on the deal released a report Sunday saying that while it has flaws, Iran should accept it. However, it did not call for a vote by the Majlis. Comparison class: The whole thing is reminiscent of the U.S. House and Senate finally dropping this hot potato. It doesn't look to me like either side in the Majlis has figured out a way to benefit. Chances look good that instead they will toss this hot potato to the Assembly of Experts. So… is this question about to close? Will the Majlis vote on it anyhow, or give the thankless job to the Assembly of Experts? The fact that today, police hauled away protesters against the deal demonstrating in front of the Majlis suggests that the powers that be have decided the deal will go through, but by avoiding a Majlis vote in order to avoid the pain and suffering and potential for fatlaities that could occur if demonstrations against the deal were to morph into riots. Sources: Dateline 10-5-15 Reports suggest that the opposition sit-in in front of parliament Iran nuclear deal with the six world powers ended with the intervention of the police. They were camped in front of parliament... http://www.radiofarda.com/content/b32-iran-nuclear-agreemnet-majlis-opponents/27285206.html Dateline 10-4-15 A panel of Iranian lawmakers said Sunday that the inspections regime underpinning the country's nuclear deal with world powers represented a security threat, but the agreement should go ahead anyway. The 15-member committee spent weeks reviewing the text of the July 14 agreement, known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), for what it said could be breaches of negotiators' "red lines".  http://www.i24news.tv/en/news/international/87915-151004-iran-nuclear-review-panel-says-deal-flawed Dateline 10-2-15 ...The implementation of the deal is very likely to happen, but the means of getting there are unclear, and domestic critics will seek to maintain room for maneuver. ...only Ayatollah Ali Khamenei or the Guardian Council -- which has the exclusive right of interpreting the constitution -- can determine which institution, the Majlis (parliament) or the Supreme National Security Council (SNSC), should ultimately endorse the JCPOA. Both Khamenei and the Guardian Council have called on parliament to review the JCPOA but have not specified or recommended that the Majlis vote on the deal before it is referred to the SNSC. President Hassan Rouhani prefers that the SNSC approve the deal without a Majlis vote. Even members of parliament have been mum on whether their discussion of the JCPOA report, drafted by a special committee, will be followed by a vote or whether the legislators' comments will be sent along to the SNSC for final approval. Also uncertain is a deadline for conclusion of the parliamentary debate and possible vote, although some legislators have said the discussion should be concluded as soon as possible. http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/irans-majlis-unlikely-to-settle-internal-dispute-on-the-nuclear-deal
The committee approved it and now it goes to Parliament.
Further to khalid http://www.irna.ir/en/News/81784419/.  Not sure of the single vs. Double urgency issue....

DUBAI (Reuters) - - An committee of Iran's conservative-dominated parliament gave its support on Sunday to Iran's nuclear agreement with world powers on condition there would be no foreign inspections of military sites and no curbs on developing its missile program. and http://sputniknews.com/middleeast/20151004/1027995370/nuclear-iran-deal-approval.html The Islamic Consultative Assembly approved the implementation of the nuclear deal on Sunday, the Iranian IRNA news agency said.  The lawmakers voted after examining a report by the commission set up to look into the text of the nuclear deal, according to the news outlet. Comment : This is as close to approval as we are going to see. However, the condition set of no foreign inspection of military sites has implications for the latest question on whether disputes concerning undeclared nuclear sites will be referred upwards.

Trying to predict the scorers instead of reality. I don't see that the likely result will be an actual approval, but am raising probability under protest, given the past behaviours of scorers.

https://www.aei.org/publication/is-iran-already-gaming-the-nuclear-deal/ September 28, 2015  "As we approach the deal’s October 19 Adoption Day anticipated by the United Nations Security Council, there is no indication that Iran is backing away from the JCPOA. That has not stopped Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khamenei from letting the parliament and hardline critics from having a go at the JCPOA’s flaws, especially if that helps check President Hassan Rouhani’s popular support. The special parliamentary commission established to review the JCPOA has frequently taken an adversarial stance towards the deal and the president over the past few weeks. "Parliament Speaker Ali Larijani, a current ally of Rouhani, has rushed the commission’s review under a “double emergency plan” mechanism. . . .  Parliamentarian and Commission Spokesman Hossein Naghavi Hosseini stated the final report will likely recommend a resolution that will neither “accept” nor “reject” the nuclear deal, but instead would “provisionally approve” the JCPOA. This gives the parliament its say without hampering the administration’s ability to maneuver. "Once the report is read in parliament, there will be plenty of spin designed to obscure the realities of the deal and appease domestic audiences. . . . Expect to see a litany of assertions about what the JCPOA does and does not compel Iran to do. Officials will argue the agreement does not restrict Iran’s missile activity, and that sanctions relief should be immediate per the Supreme Leader’s redlines. ". . .  Iranian officials’ insistence on weighing their options could be seen as simply foot-dragging, or as a prelude to a more serious effort to game the terms of the JCPOA. The Iranian leadership also needs these public debates to prevent Tehran’s compliance with the deal from appearing as capitulation to the West.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  The bottom-line for me is that I just do not see Khamenei, Rouhani & Larijani allowing this to fail to be approved, because they've already risked so much politically to get it to this point. I am firmly of the opinion that a "provisional approval"  is an approval and would satisfy this question as "yes".

This could make it interesting if not vetoed before majles votes.  Possibly why Ayatollah Ali Khamenei wanted them to vote on it with the three clear caveats as to why to fail it, in case of such moves.  Not lifting sanctions was the key one.  Moving slightly away from certain for now, as think it will resolve itself, but will be watching the timing issues that may cause me to adjust within the timeframe.

"JCPOA review commission: We won’t be able to submit report tomorrow. Hossein Naghavi Hosseini stated on September 29 that the time at which Parliament’s JCPOA Commission will submit its report to Parliament “cannot be announced because still some committee reports and related issues remain. It is therefore unlikely that the report will reach tomorrow’s public session in Parliament.” The Special Parliamentary Commission to Review the JPCOA Spokesman said that the commission will draw up the “final report in the next few days,” and that “certainly, the final report… will be read in Parliament by Sunday of next week [October 4].” (ICANA)
...
Pezeshkian: JCPOA review commission needs more time. Special Parliamentary Commission to Review the JPCOA member Massoud Pezeshkian said, “Not only are disputes a barrier to concluding [the report], but also if we want our views to be closer to one another, we [the Commission members] need more time and more scientific evidence.” Pezeshkian also criticized Parliament Speaker Ali Larijani’s comments on the JCPOA at an earlier commission meeting, stating, “As someone who has spent hours in the Supreme National Security Council and in the service of the Supreme Leader at meetings on the nuclear negotiations and the JCPOA, Larijani cannot have an unacceptable opinion about the JCPOA.” (YJC)
...
Parliamentarian Hossein Sobhani Nia discussed Parliament’s review of the JCPOA and stated, “The ball is now in Iran’s court… The defensive, political, legal aspects [of the nuclear deal] in addition to the implementation of the Additional Protocol, sanctions, and snapback sanctions must be considered.” The National Security and Foreign Policy (NSFP) Parliamentary Commission member added, “Therefore, it is arranged that a double-emergency plan will be presented [to Parliament] which both permits the administration to implement the contents of the JCPOA and also considers the general interests of the political system.” (ICANA)"

Well, darn, this is one of those questions in which the behaviour of the scorers will be more important than the actual facts. The reason for this is that this question is actually several questions and it is up to us forecasters to guess what the real question is in the minds of the scorers. I understand that IARPA has serious concerns about the need to decompose questions into their component parts, given how often GJP has developed problems with this given the current abilities of those who generate questions and refuse to give clarifications. My understanding is that only in the first two forecast seasons did the CIA provide questions. Sigh. If anyone knows otherwise, please correct me.  It looks like Iran's Parliament will vote on "red lines" etc. rather than a formal adoption of the agreement. So when they do vote, the mainstream media will simplify the results, the scorers will accept simplifications, and it will turn out like the controversial Parchin question. For this reason I am increasing the probability but under protest.

http://www.theguardian.com/world/iran-blog/2015/sep/30/iran-us-handshake-parliament-nuclear-deal Article covers the confusion as to what the Iranian Parliament actually needs to do regarding the Agreement.  Positive statements from the Parliament are encouraging.
Probably part of their play book but it may occur later than 11/1
The different pieces of the deal are falling into place more quickly than I originally estimated. So, upping estimate..

Comparison class: In the end, Republicans in the U.S. Congress made lots of noises about the nuclear deal, knowing full well they had no chance of scuttling it. Their pursuit of this hopless cause was designed to keep their voters happy and raise lots of money for their upcoming campaigns. Democrats also managed to keep their voters happy and raise campaign money, knowing full well that the deal would not come up for a vote.  Likewise, Iran's hardliners are merely making a show of opposition, knowing full well that the agreement won't even come up for a vote. It's all just a show. Source: Dateline 9-28-15 Al-Monitor sat down with former Foreign Ministry spokesman Hamid Reza Asefi to get a sense of the situation. “It’s very good that parliament is becoming involved in the serious issues that our country faces, and there is no problem with this. But exactly how parliament plans to do this, and whether it wants to discuss details or generalities, are things that we have to wait to see,” said Asefi. He qualified his comments and said, “In the end, though, I don’t think parliament will involve itself in the ratification or rejection of the JCPOA, since doing so will have serious consequences.” Indeed, what has stirred debate more than the potential outcome of the commission’s “review” is the presence of former nuclear negotiators in its sessions. Saeed Jalili, a conservative who ran in the 2013 presidential election, was never required to answer questions in parliament when he led negotiations in 2007-13. Yet, these days, he and his team see it as their duty to provide answers. In a hard-hitting attack on the nuclear deal before the commission, Jalili outlined what he called 100 “violations” of Iran’s “rights.” Despite the harsh language, this sort of opposition is not widely seen as a credible threat to the deal. According to Mehdi Motaharinia, a political analyst on international issues, “The presence of Jalili and the former negotiating team is only aimed at showing public opinion that they had also worked hard to make the nuclear file a success, and through their current presence [in the commission], they hope to distance themselves from their own failures.” Behrouz Nemati, the former spokesman for parliament’s presiding board, also echoes this sentiment. He told Al-Monitor, “Jalili’s presence at the commission is like bringing the dead back to life, which is not possible. Jalili should instead answer as to why he destroyed all the opportunities that came up during the six years that he was in charge of the nuclear file, and why he did not bring the [2013] Almaty [Kazakhstan] talks to conclusion.” But the story doesn’t end here. Perhaps the most striking aspect of the establishment of this commission is the Rouhani administration's and the negotiating team’s opposition to it. Asefi told Al-Monitor, “What the negotiating team has said is that parliament should not ratify the JCPOA. But they never said that there should not be a commission to review the nuclear deal. They also said that parliament should not become involved in the ratification or rejection of the deal.” Asefi added, “The reason that the president, the foreign minister and nuclear negotiating team say parliament should not ratify the deal is because no parliament in the P5+1 [Russia, China, Britain, France, United States and Germany] group of countries has done this. Therefore, there is no need for us to ratify the deal. Second, if we do take such a measure in parliament, it will then become law, and with it, bring obligations for the government and tie our hands. Therefore, it is better if this is not done.” Read more: http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/09/iran-jcpoa-review-commission.html#ixzz3nB9IKPZB

The special JCPOA commission will apparently report to the parliament today, and concurrent with their report they are preparing a double-urgency bill for parliament concerning the implementation of the JCPOA [1]. A double-urgency bill apparently puts the bill at the top of the legislative agenda, so I expect a vote would come quickly. I believe the vote is largely symbolic, intended to involve Iranian domestic politics in the negotiation in a way that mirrors the influence of US domestic politics through Congress. Nonetheless, I expect the vote to resolve in favor of the JCPOA. However, I have some question about the content of the double-urgency bill and whether its passage will constitute a "yes" for the purposes of this question. On September 21, Chairman of the Parliament’s National Security and Foreign Policy Commission Alaeddin Boroujerdi said that Parliament would neither pass nor reject the JCPOA, but rather establish red-lines around its implementation [2]. This may have something to do with concerns that explicit parliamentary approval would bind the government to adhere to a protocol that would otherwise be voluntary [3]. Would such a vote on "red-lines" constitute "approval"? Overall, I am going to guess that it would, since the question doesn't use a more specific term like "ratification". [1] http://en.trend.az/iran/politics/2437937.html
[2] http://en.trend.az/iran/nuclearp/2435758.html
[3] http://iranmatters.belfercenter.org/blog/explainer-iranian-review-nuclear-deal

No. The deal will pass the Iranian Parliament but not before Nov. 1. It will pass because a parliament is still beholden to popular opinion even in Iran, and a sizeable swath of the population is supportive ofthe deal as evidence by the rock star status of the foreign minister. The deal will pass only after the reactionary factions have had their vocal say so that if the deal falls through the supreme leader can say I told you so "the satan cannot be trusted." This is why the supreme leader has been publicily nay-saying the deal while still allowing it to happen: insurance. Also, for internal politics it helps his standing with the ultra conservative factions.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NYJZj7qux_c PRESIDENT ROUHANI: The majority of our people, in opinion polls, have a positive view of the agreement. And usually institutions like the parliament and the Supreme National Security Council are usually not far-removed from public opinion and move in that direction. KROFT: The debate is expected to be very heated in the parliament. Do you think that there’s a chance that the agreement could be rejected? Either by the Parliament or the Security Council or by the Ayatollah? PRESIDENT ROUHANI: In any event, in the world of possibilities, every possibility exists. But I believe the logic of those who are in favor of the deal, is a very strong logic.
They will vote but not approve.

"Parliamentarian Hossein Naghavi Hosseini discussed the final report of the Special Commission to Review the JCPOA in an interview with Tasnim News Agency on September 22.  The Special Parliamentary Commission to Review the JCPOA Spokesman said that the commission’s final report would likely recommend that a resolution be drawn up on the JCPOA. This resolution, Naghavi claimed, would not “accept” nor “reject” the nuclear deal. Instead, Hosseini argued, it would “provisionally approve” the JCPOA within the frameworks of the Supreme Leader’s “redlines.”  (Tasnim News Agency)" "Parliamentarian Mohammad Hossein Farhangi discussed the parliamentary review of the JCPOA during an interview with ICANA News Agency. The Parliament’s Board of Directors member said that that lawmakers will likely “draw up and present” a resolution that would allow the government to implement its commitments as stated in the JCPOA. (ICANA)"

If I understand things correctly, the role of the Iranian Parliament concerning the JCPOA is similar to that of the US Congress–Parliament doesn't necessarily have to approve the deal, while a vote against would endanger it. Thus not going through with a vote may be an attractive way to appease hardliners, and it has been reported that Parliament will "rather pass red-lines as a necessity and allow the government to implement its agreement with the 5+1":  http://tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=249580 So the scenario described below by Agent0090 may be somewhat likely: "[Parliament allows] approval through something short of a vote (like the issuance of a favorable report, possibly followed by a vote that "adopts" the report without explicitly "approving" the JCPOA), it gives everyone what they want while still allowing some wiggle room in future if things go south." [quote from Agent0090's post] True, Rouhani et al. would probably benefit from having a parliamentary approval of the JCPOA as a part of a broader strategy of moderation (see link below about an emergent "'pro-minimal engagement' camp" among "members of the Iranian policy elite ... [including President] Rouhani, Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif and other top officials"), even if approval isn't strictly required for things to proceed. However, the hardline faction in Parliament may not go along with this if it can allow the deal to stand without seeming to endorse it, and moderates too may prefer this as the politically safer option, since it would allow them to avoid any possible embarrassment during a vote.  http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/09/iran-deal-domestic-debate-reduce-intervention.html#ixzz3mX6zKNuQ Update: amcchile's link is especially helpful in clearing up the Rouhani administration's objection to a parliamentary vote, although the statements it cites are all around a month old.

Iran's leaders, after schmoozing the hardliners, now are working with European leaders to get the agreement moving ahead. Dateline 9-21-15 International Atomic Energy Agency chief Yukiya Amano testified Sept. 20 before an Iranian special committee to review the country's comprehensive nuclear deal with the five permanent members of the UN Security Council plus Germany (P5+1). The presence of the IAEA chief in front of the conservative-led parliament gave the Iranian members of parliament an opportunity to air long-held grievances against the agency.... While Iranian members of parliament continued to debate the nuclear deal, President Hassan Rouhani and Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif continue their outreach to European countries anticipating the end of sanctions. On Sept. 21, Dutch Foreign Minister Bert Koenders visited Tehran, meeting separately with Rouhani, Zarif, head of parliament Ali Larijani and Supreme National Security Council Secretary Ali Shamkhani. 
Read more: http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/09/amano-iaea-iran-parliament.html

http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/iaea-chief-visits-irans-controversial-parchin-site-493329814#sthash.6kRqMXOV.dpuf On the other hand:

http://en.trend.az/iran/nuclearp/2435758.html Looking back the original article, it seems that a parliamentary vote was ordered by Khamenei back when U.S. Republicans were making noises about the next president not being bound by the deal. Now IAEA had has smoothed over Parchin and participated in a session of the parliamentary committee reviewing the JCPOA. I think that public opinion is overwhelmingly in favor of the deal, and that if it comes to a parliamentary vote it will pass. This may actually be bad news for the hard liners because it locks in approval of the deal. If they allow approval through something short of a vote (like the issuance of a favorable report, possibly followed by a vote that "adopts" the report without explicitly "approving" the JCPOA), it gives everyone what they want while still allowing some wiggle room in future if things go south.   So I'm lowering my forecast to allow for the possibility of the JCPOA moving forward without a formal parliamentary vote of approval. I'll be watching this one closely over the next couple of days, and I welcome other thoughts on the issue.

Lowering probability to 85%. I enjoyed a long discussion with a journalist  friend who has in-depth knowledge of Iran's hard liners. He thinks they may well see this as the beginning of the end for them. Lifting of sanctions means more influence for the business community;  it means more involvement with the outside world for average citizens. Overall, Iran already appears to be the most stable, educated, civilized and tolerant nation in the region. My friend says that thanks to a fatwah by Ayatolla Khomeini that still is in effect, Jewish synagogues  are safer there than in much of Europe. Jews openly wear yarmulkes, even prayer shawls, in public. There even is a Jewish member of the Parliament. Given all of this, the end of sanctions can only make the nation more modern and less revolutionary. Comparison class: The Ku Klux Klan, a U.S. racist, terrorist organization responsible for countless riots, murders, bombings and arsons, used to be so acceptable that high ranking politicians used to be members. They even included Presidents. Yet it was former Ku Klux Klan member President Harry Truman who integrated the armed forces by executive order. Yes, people can change, no matter how invested in acts of hatred. One might expect Iranian hard liners to fear something similar as the walls fall down between their Islamic revolution and the world. I asked about the virulent opposition to the deal by Netanyau. Wouldn't this tell the hard liners that ratifying the deal would inflict a defeat against Netanyahu's forces, whom they would prefer to wipe off the face of the planet.  My friend says that Iranian hard liners see Netanyahu's opposition as a political ploy, that he is looking for a way to get U.S. politicians to back him up by making war against Iran. Hard liners believe there is no way to placate Netanyahu.

MPs demand Amano's presence in parliamentary commission
Tehran, Sept 16, IRNA – Members of the parliamentary commission in charge of examining the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) have called for IAEA Director-General Yukiya Amano to brief the commission. Alireza Zakani, head of the parliamentary commission, on Wednesday submitted a letter to Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif demanding that Amano brief the parliamentary commission. 
The letter comes as Amano is due to visit Iran in coming days. 
In his letter, Zakani said the lawmakers want to have a meeting with Amano to express their views to the IAEA chief. 
He also said that Amano may have points to explain to Iranian MPs. 
Zakani said that as Amano has attended the US Congress and delivered a report to the US congresspersons on the JCPOA, he has to do the same in Iran.
Looking better as Khameini, Rouhani and Zarif make the rounds of power players, pressing the case for approval. By building consensus, they are making approval a win-win for everyone.

Madre's Business Week article gave an interesting perspective. Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, considered the architect of the deal, cut Parliament out of the negotiations. Parliament, under prior Presidents, Ahmadinejad, etc., participated in the actual negotiations.  Khamenei, also has limited the power of Presidents to prevent them from gaining to much influence. When President Rouhani requested the agreement be approved by the Supreme National Security Council (which Rouhani heads), Khemenei ordered that Parliament vote on it. The benefits are the elimination of sanctions and the legitimization of a low level nucular capability for medical research and power generation.  Ali Larijani, head of the Iranian Parliament, expects the Parliament to vote toward the end of September.   On September 28th, 2015, both Obama and Rouhani are scheduled to speak at the UN.  The timing of the US and Iranian approvals are close to this date.  Assuming that Iran would like to get to "Implementation Day" as soon as possible, the vote may be timed either to 1. allow Rouhani to make the announcement at the UN, or 2. slightly after, if Rouhani is prevented from receiving the publicity at the UN.  But a delay, after US approval, later than early October, seem unlikely.

There are a couple of different factors that may affect the vote: (1) In a June survey, a solid majority of Iranians expressed support for a nuclear deal, so long as it brought sanctions relief (source: http://www.cissm.umd.edu/publications/iranian-public-opinion-nuclear-negotiations). As the current deal meets that condition, parliamentarians will be under some pressure to see it through. (2) All candidates for parliament must be approved by Iran's Guardian Council, which is selected by the Supreme Leader and the head of the judiciary. As a result, there is a strong incentive for current parliamentarians who wish to run in future elections to stay in alignment with the Ayatollah's general policy preferences; if they don't, they risk being disqualified. While Khamenei has yet to endorse the final deal (creating some uncertainty), I find it difficult to believe that he would let the process get this far and then torpedo it. As this Reuters article (http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/09/15/us-iran-nuclear-setad-insight-idUSKCN0RF0E920150915) also points out, many of Khamenei's close supporters stand to benefit from the deal, increasing his incentive to see it pass.  (3) While there are a large number of hardliner members of parliament, I don't seem to be able to find a credible source nailing down an exact number (Iranian political affiliations seems to be quite fluid). However, very few news articles are suggesting that there are enough hardliners opposed to torpedo the deal (will update if I can find better info on this).

While Madre has an excellent roundup of news articles, I found the majority of them to be hugely myopic with respect to the deal. One cranky old hat stirring up anti-Western sentiment doesn't suddenly mean passage will fail. Just as the Congressional vote was (almost) assured from the start but allowed hard-liners to bare their teeth, so too are the latest comments coming from Iran. For reference, in the past week alone President Rouhani offered "L'shana tova" to Israel and SL Khameini denounced Israel and called us The Great Satan again. (Personally, it's my favorite nickname for the U.S.) I'm placing a lot of eggs in this basket between all the similar questions, but I reiterate my stance: Iran can, will and MUST pass this accord. Khameini has already rubber-stamped the deal or else it wouldn't exist in the first place, and now he simply has to reassure his allies with the usual rhetoric. As far as I see it, the ONLY question remaining is the timeline for approval. Iran's parliament was directed to wait at least 80 days from the JCPOA's inking, which comes due on October 9th. At least one (questionable) source has the vote coming as soon as this month. Based on these, I find the probability of passage before Nov 1st to be very high. http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/22/world/middleeast/iran-nuclear-deal-vote.html

Some thoughts with links below: The Ayatollah made favorable comments about the JCPOA prior to the vote in Congress; however, his tone switched late last week... after the vote.  Curiously too, the day after Congress passed the agreement, Iran announced a visit to China to discuss said agreement (also economic alliances).    Iran's parliament is made up of conservatives. It's leader, Larijani hedged recently when asked in a variety of recent stateside interviews (see Amanpour/CNN and Inskeep/NPR) whether JCPOA will "pass".  His view is that that Iran will not sign anything until sanctions are lifted. The U.S. has said sanctions can be lifted in as soon as six months (Jan).  Note too that as the JCPOA is right now the Rouhani sees it as a loose voluntary agreement without his signature. If it goes through Parliament it will become legally "binding" for Iran but not so for the other countries who signed it. Now members are scrutinizing the agreement that Rouhani left them out of when it was built. Khomeini isn't stepping in to get them to align right now (eventually he likely will whereas they likely will sign off on the agreement - but for now he's punishing Rouhani for his power hungry actions). Rouhani is trying hard to be relevant to maintain power well into the future. This weekend (during the time of the year which is a pause for reflection and repentance in the ME), Rouhani tweeted "L'Shanah Tovah" to Israel while blasting the Saudi's over crane incompetence.   Also note that many posts/predictions on the Rezaian question see his release soon. Parliament Chief Larijani's brother is the leader of Iran's judiciary wing. While the institutions the bros Larijani represent are separate, the two are said to be close kin. A Parliament wait on the JCPOA means a Judiciary wait on Rezaian. Oh, and first and most importantly, Khomeini needs to give his blessing on Rezaian before anything can happen.   Ayatollah flip flop:
